quizzes.question:
What does this list comprehension create?
nums = [i*2 for i in range(10)]
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Comprehensions[/h1]

[b]List comprehensions[/b] are a useful way of quickly creating lists whose contents obey a simple rule.
For example, we can do the following: [code format="py" codeId="372"]# a list comprehension
[b]cubes = [i**3 for i in range(5)][/b]

print(cubes)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[0, 1, 8, 27, 64]
>>>[/code]
[note]List comprehensions are inspired by set-builder notation in mathematics.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Create a list of multiples of 3 from 0 to 20.
[!raw!]
a = {0}i for i in range(20) {1} i%{2}==0]
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Comprehensions[/h1]

A list comprehension can also contain an [b]if[/b] statement to enforce a condition on values in the list.
[b]Example:[/b][code format="py" codeId="373"]evens=[i**2 for i in range(10)[b] if i**2 % 2 == 0[/b]]

print(evens)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[0, 4, 16, 36, 64]
>>> [/code]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to create a list of numbers multiplied by 10 in the range of 5 to 9.
[!raw!]
a = [x*10 {0} x {1} range({2}, 9)]
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Comprehensions[/h1]

Trying to create a list in a very extensive range will result in a [b]MemoryError[/b].
This code shows an example where the list comprehension runs out of memory. [code format="py" codeId="374"]even = [2*i for i in range(10**100)][/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
MemoryError
>>>[/code]
[note]This issue is solved by [b]generators[/b], which are covered in the next module.[/note]
